content: no word for this mystery, no Saying which could bring Being of language to language: “word for the being of the word is not granted”

linkedContent: no word for this mystery, no Saying which could bring Being of language to language: “word for the being of the word is not granted”

content: what is more truly worthy [of poet’s thought, of thought] than word’s being veiling itself, the fading word for the word > oldest word for rule of word: logos—the same word, word for Saying, is word for Being, the presencing of beings
linkedContent: what is more truly worthy [of poet’s thought, of thought] than word’s being veiling itself, the fading word for the word > oldest word for rule of word: logos—the same word, word for Saying, is word for Being, the presencing of beings

content: in order to fittingly follow element worthy of thought (as it gives itself to poetry [is that the key distinction?]) : abandon everything which we have now said to oblivion
